The Cult of the Big Bang: Was There a Bang?
William C Mitchell
(p169-170)

â€œIt is assumed, as it is in virtually all cosmology articles, that the occurrence of the [Big Bang] is not to be questioned; only how the universe can be explained with it ...

[I]n his book The Big Bang (1980), Silk told us, 'Today the central questions of cosmology and cosmogony are being explored within the framework of Big Bang Theory' ...

Probably many 1000s of scientist man-hours have been spent in this quest to prove that the density of the universe is sufficiently high to provide for a flat or closed [Big Bang] universe, and to prove the presence of CDM that is thought necessary to explain giant galactic formations.  If sufficient matter is not found, space cannot have positive curvature.  Without that curvature the [Big Bang]er's case for photons from the decoupling arriving from all directions is without merit, and their most important evidence in support of the [Big Bang] is invalid."
